bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Laura Wood, February 3, 1942

div1.p: Hench informs Wood that the Surgeon General's library had no record of the Reed-Lazear notebook ever being catalogued. He suggests she visit Reed's family members for permission to use Walter Reed's letters.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Laura Wood, February 3, 1942
div1.opener:
Y. F.
February 3, 1942
My dear Miss Wood:
div1.p:
I am returning to you the four photostated pages from the
Lazear-Reed notebook as I now have my own copy. Let me thank you again for
your real kindness in letting me know of this book. By the way, if you ever
find no further use for your four photostats, I would like to have them,
especially that on page 37. They made my photostats very hastily and many
of them are very sloppy. My photostat of page 37 is not nearly as good as
yours.

I spent a morning at the Surgeon General's library and we could
find no evidence that this notebook had ever been catalogued. The chief librar-
ian was out but Dr. Mayer, the librarian responsible for cataloging all the
books spent some time with me. He was greatly interested in the book and its
history. He seemed very gratified when I promised to let him have my photostats
so that they could make themselves a copy for their library. He seemed satis-
fied to consider the matter closed and therefore I told him a lot of what Dr.
Malloch had told me. On his assurance that the matter was closed, I inquired
as to whether a man by the name of Wormley had ever worked there. A colored man
by that name used to work in the Surgeon General's office, in the medical de-
partment but as I understand it, not for some years. Dr. Mayer estimated that
he must be in his fifties now, so that he might be a relative of Dr. Lowell
Cheatban Wormley who was in the directory. The latter was born in 1906 and is
the man whose name you and I both found in the directory. Dr. Mayer told me
it is quite possible that the old notebook might well have been thrown out.
Like us, he was a little suspicious of the whole thing but not inclined to press
matters. The question now is whether Dr. Wormley is the man who actually sold
the book or the man who was an intermediary between the seller and Malloch.
Malloch sent me the following note: “In November, 1931, Dr. - -, an interne at
the - Hospital, told Dr. - that he had Walter Reed's notebook of cases of
yellow fever. Before Dr. - brought the book to me, I heard, third-handed, that
when he was working as a medical student one summer at the Army Medical Library,
he had rescued the book from an ash barrel...” I think Malloch is going to get
in touch with Wormley to see if he has any more Reed material.

Before leaving, Mrs. Hench and I called your home once Tuesday
evening about 5:30 and twice Wednesday, but no one was at home.

May I urge you strongly to do two things: (1) By all means call
in person on Mrs. Blossom Reed and her mother. She may not have the copies of
the letters in Washington but you should meet her and her mother anyhow and if
you find that the reception is a friendly one (and I sincerely believe it will be)
you may be able to make some such statement as the following: “Am I correct in
my understanding that you let Dr. Hench make a copy of many of these letters? If
so, would you be willing to let me write him and ask him to lend me his copy since
yours is not in Washington?” With her authorization I shall be glad to lend it to
Miss Laura Wood
- 2 -
February 3, 1942
you. Perhaps it is too late now to bother about that. (2) By all means, if you
haven't already done so, go to the Archives Building and see Mr. R. R. Critchfield
in the old records division of the Adjutant General's office. They have the per-
sonal report files of Walter Reed showing his complete whereabouts throughout his
entire army career with each report signed in his own handwriting. These were
monthly reports. They are in much greater detail than the synopsis of his where-
abouts as generally given out by the War Department. General Reed, Walter Reed's
son, believes that his father was at Fort Snelling from May or June, 1891 to
September, 1892 and in St. Paul from September, 1892 to September, 1893. I didn't
have time to check these dates with Reed's monthly reports but you will find all
of that data in one file. I don't know whether mentioning my name will help or
hurt you. Critchfield wasn't very helpful at first until General Ireland put some
pressure on him in my behalf. Because of this he was very nice at the last but
nevertheless he may have resented Ireland's interference in my behalf and I think
it might be best for you merely to say that you are writing up the life of Walter
Reed, have had some help from the Reed family and others and you understand that
the personal record file is in their office. You will be allowed to copy some of
this material and have it censored by Critchfield. They are very wary about
photostats.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
